title: 107_hr5297
content: The Act may be cited as the "Health Care Continuation Coverage Act of 2002" and provides premium assistance for COBRA continuation coverage. The "Health Care Continuation Coverage Act of 2002" establishes a program for premium assistance for COBRA continuation coverage for qualified individuals who elect such coverage. Premium assistance provided under this section for COBRA continuation coverage ends when the individual is no longer covered under COBRA or 12 months after enrollment in the program. The assistance covers 100% of the required premium and is paid through direct payment arrangements with the administrator. Premium assistance for COBRA continuation coverage is provided through direct payment arrangements with the plan administrator. The administrator has a fiduciary duty to enter into these arrangements. The assistance reduces the premiums owed by the individual. Changes in COBRA notices are also specified. The COBRA continuation coverage notices must include an additional notification about the availability of premium assistance. The Secretary of the Treasury will ensure alternative notices are provided if the standard notice does not apply. The notification requirement can be fulfilled in various forms. The COBRA continuation coverage notices must include an additional notification with specific requirements for eligibility and enrollment, contact information for plan administrators, and a prominent statement. The COBRA continuation coverage notices must include a prominent statement informing individuals of potential assistance with payment of 100% of their premiums for up to 12 months. For notices sent before the enactment of this Act, additional notification must be provided within 60 days for eligible individuals who have elected or are still eligible to elect COBRA coverage. The Secretary will prescribe models for additional notification required under this subsection. This section constitutes budget authority in advance of appropriations Acts for premium assistance. The Secretary of the Treasury must issue guidance within 30 days of enactment. Definitions include "administrator" and "COBRA continuation coverage." COBRA continuation coverage refers to continuation coverage provided under specific laws, including the Public Health Service Act and the Internal Revenue Code. A group health plan is defined as per the Internal Revenue Code. The term "State" includes various regions like the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. The regions covered under COBRA continuation coverage include Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY MEDICAID COVERAGE FOR CERTAIN UNINSURED EMPLOYEES. Temporary Medicaid coverage is provided for individuals who have lost their job after July 1, 2001, are not eligible for COBRA, and are uninsured. Coverage extends to their spouse and dependents. Assistance ends when the individual gains insurance or after 12 months. Temporary Medicaid coverage is available for individuals who lost their job after July 1, 2001, are not eligible for COBRA, and are uninsured. Coverage includes their spouse and dependents and ends when the individual gains insurance or after 12 months. Federal assistance percentage is enhanced, and states can choose alternative income limits. (4) Individuals eligible for medical assistance under this section are considered to be described in the list preceding paragraph (1) of section 1905(a) of the Act; (5) States can provide medical assistance without limitations under certain sections of the Act, and no debt will accrue under an affidavit of support for sponsors of alien individuals receiving assistance; (6) The Secretary of Health and Human Services will not count certain costs for Social Security purposes. For section 1108(f) of the Social Security Act, payments under this section should be proportional to national payments under title XIX for all states and the District of Columbia. The term "uninsured" refers to individuals not covered by group health plans, health insurance, or specific programs under titles XVIII, XIX, or XXI of the Social Security Act. The term "COBRA continuation coverage" refers to employer-provided group health plan coverage under specific laws. The term "State" has the same meaning as in title XIX of the Social Security Act. Coverage under certain titles does not include excepted benefits. The term "COBRA continuation coverage" refers to employer-provided group health plan coverage under specific laws. The term "State" has the same meaning as in title XIX of the Social Security Act. This section shall take effect upon its enactment, regardless of regulations being issued. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY COVERAGE FOR UNSUBSIDIZED PORTION OF COBRA CONTINUATION PREMIUMS. As a condition for receiving Federal financial assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act, a State must pay the unsubsidized portion of COBRA continuation coverage premiums for individuals who became separated from employment on or after July 1, 2001, and have elected COBRA coverage. Premium assistance ends when the individual is no longer covered. The individual's premium assistance under COBRA continuation coverage ends either when they are no longer covered or 12 months after becoming eligible. States providing assistance are entitled to financial payment under the Social Security Act, similar to medical assistance, with adjustments for the enhanced FMAP. The unsubsidized portion of premium for COBRA continuation coverage refers to the part of the premium without financial assistance. This section will take effect upon enactment, regardless of issued regulations. SEC. 5 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include compensation under the State's unemployment compensation law. This amendment does not apply to certification periods starting before the enactment of this Act.
